history.content:
No, CS 189 does not assume you've taken EECS 127. But, having taken EECS 127 will help significantly with getting the most out of 189 since machine learning problems can be viewed as optimization problems (i.e. 127 will help you shape the way you think about problems in 189, instead of just "tackling it with math"). 

If you've only taken 54/70, then I wouldn't recommend you take CS 189 until you build up some mathematical maturity (take Math 110 to build on Lin. Alg., an upper div. probability course like 134 or EECS 126, and perhaps a statistics class like 135). You will struggle a lot without a sufficient mathematical background.

Just FYI, getting into Math 110 might be a bit difficult as a non-math major since they just changed enrollment policies within the math department (you can't enroll as a non-math major during P1; not sure about P2).

If you've only taken 54/70, then I wouldn't recommend you take CS 189 until you build up some mathematical maturity (take Math 110 to build on Lin. Alg., an upper div. probability course like 134 or EECS 126, and perhaps a statistics class like 135). You will struggle a lot without a sufficient mathematical background.

children.subject: I've heard from students that you get a lot more out of the class from CS 189 if you've taken EECS 127 before/concurrently, so personally I would put off a semester. I've never done research, so I honestly wouldn't be able to tell you if you will be able to do it alongside those 2 classes (I think the best bet is to go Math 110 -> 127 -> 189, or 110 -> 127/189.
I'd say not completely necessary to do 110 before 127.  Just make sure your linear algebra is very solid.  See my follow-up below.

I've taken STAT 134, and currently taking STAT 135, but my linear algebra background is just MATH 54. Would you recommend putting off a semester to take MATH 110/EE 127 first? If so, which one would you recommend? I am a little bit concerned about the time since I am currently a sophomore now, and if I take CS 189 in junior spring, I don't really have time to do research in junior year. But CS 189 professor in spring seems better, and his past grade distribution is also better (Fall 2016 VS Spring 2017).

Agreed with student response -- optimization is used in (new/revamped) CS189, and it did get a bit technical with Lagrangian duality but I think because non-127 students struggled, they decided not to include it on the exams.  Thus, a background in optimization is helpful and complementary to what you learn in 189, but not completely necessary.

BUT I have heard they are gradually ramping up the difficulty/maturity level of CS189, so EECS 127 could be more necessary in future offerings.

As for prep for 127, whether you take it before/concurrently/after 189, I would say a very solid grasp of Math 54 plus self-teaching SVD/PCA would suffice.  I struggled in the beginning of 127 because my linear algebra was not at the maturity level demanded.  That said, I wouldn't spend a semester trying to fit in Math 110 prior to 127.  With discipline, one could do lots of (theoretical, not mechanical) linear algebra review and also learn about SVD/PCA (taught in EE16B) before the semester begins.  127 actually goes over SVD and PCA from bottom-up, so if you're a fast learner, self-studying may not be necessary.

history.content:
Does CS 189 assume EE 127 knowledge, or does CS 189 teaches those topics without assuming you know them?

The draft schedule says that Prof. Recht is going to teach CS 189 next fall, and Prof. Shewchuk next spring. Can someone who took CS 189 with these two professors share their opinions?

Thx so much!

P.S. I've taken MATH 54 and haven't taken EE 16A&16B
history.subject: Does CS 189 assumes EE 127 knowledge?
